plants.name: Rudbeckia hirta
plants.description: A hardy North American wildflower with bright yellow ray florets and a dark brown central cone. Commonly found in prairies and meadows, it attracts pollinators like bees and butterflies.
plants.funFact: Black-eyed Susans were named after the resemblance of their dark centers to a pupil surrounded by yellow petals.

plants.name: Hibiscus rosa-sinensis
plants.description: A tropical shrub known for its large, showy flowers that bloom all year round in warm climates, but prominently during late summer into autumn. Flowers come in a range of vibrant colors.
plants.bloomingSeason: Year-round in tropical climates, peaks in late summer to autumn
plants.location: Tropical and subtropical Asia, cultivated worldwide in warm regions
plants.funFact: Each hibiscus flower typically lasts only a single day, opening in the morning and closing by sunset.

plants.name: Dahlia pinnata
plants.description: Originating from Mexico, dahlias are tuberous plants that bloom in late summer to autumn. They have diverse flower forms and colors, making them popular in ornamental gardens.
plants.location: Mexico and Central America; widely cultivated worldwide
plants.funFact: Dahlias were declared the national flower of Mexico in 1963.

plants.name: Solidago canadensis
plants.description: A tall, perennial wildflower with bright yellow plume-like clusters of flowers. It blooms in late summer through autumn and is common in meadows and along roadsides in temperate North America.
plants.location: North America, especially Canada and northern U.S.
plants.funFact: Goldenrod pollen is heavy and sticky and is not a major cause of hay fever; ragweed pollen, which blooms at the same time, is the real culprit.
